content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

Here is an example of how you can define such a struct and its show method in Julia:

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits{T<:Real}
    value::T
    unit::String
end

function Base.show(io::IO, fwu::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, fwu.value, " ", fwu.unit)
end
```
In this code, `FloatWithUnits` is a struct that has two fields: `value`, which can be any real number (either integer or floating point), and `unit`, which is a string representing the unit of measurement. The `show` function is defined to print out the value and unit in the desired format.

You can then create an instance of FloatWithUnits and print it:
```julia
fwu = FloatWithUnits(1.8, "meters")
println(fwu)  # Outputs: 1.8 meters
```
